return here?
Added return if ec != EBADR, other wise we will continue to add sensor URI. It is a valid sensor.
ERROR?

Added return if ec != EBADR, other wise we will continue to add sensor URI. It is a valid sensor.
unaddressed comments

https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/57559
Done

This is a valid sensor. We need else here, We want to continue to get speed and add sensor URL.
I refactored the code.
Similar to the above code style comment.

This is a valid sensor. We need else here, We want to continue to get speed and add sensor URL.
I refactored the code.
This `return` is not needed
Done
Done
Done
Be good if you reference that "This is single rotor support only, have a commented section for dual rotor support"
Done
What is the associations here ? Can you link the documentation?
Done
I would have just left as "//TODO: Add dual rotor support when Redfish adds" but oh well. This is fine expect it is dual "r"otor..
Done
These need updated to the new style
Done
wrap?
Done

What system was this tested on?  It uses an incorrect association that I don't see implemented in entity-manager, which would be the only thing capable of publishing a fan->sensor association.  In addition, it's posting the wrong parameter to Redfish, which I would've really expected someone to see if they had actually tried this code.  I'm not sure how this test could've passed with the code as written, unless maybe you were doing a unit test?

Help me understand please.  This appears as if it hasn't actually been tested, which I'm sure wasn't your intent.

Thank you for your review. I tested on the Rainier system. Fan associations are implemented in phosphor-hwmon based on what we define in associations.json.

Regarding the Redfish parameters, I understand that there may have been some confusion. Initially, I misunderstood the Redfish schema definition. I believed that 'Reading' represented the current sensor value, while 'SpeedRPM' indicated the fan speed set. As FanSpeed' could be adjusted by changing the 'Target' value of 'xyz.openbmc_project.Control.FanSpeed.

```xyz.openbmc_project.Control.FanSpeed                  interface -         -                                        -
.Target                                               property  t         10400                                    emits-change writable
xyz.openbmc_project.Sensor.Value                      interface -         -                                        -
.MaxValue                                             property  d         inf                                      emits-change writable
.MinValue                                             property  d         -inf                                     emits-change writable
.Unit                                                 property  s         "xyz.openbmc_project.Sensor.Value.Uni... emits-change writable
.Value                                                property  d         10445                                    emits-change writable```


Following an internal discussion with Matt Spinler and Gunner, I plan to remove the 'Reading' parameter, as it seems uncertain how to retrieve this value. I will correct the 'SpeedRPM' to the sensor value.

Fan sensor associations are defined in associations.json file.
https://github.com/openbmc/openbmc/blob/master/meta-ibm/recipes-phosphor/inventory/phosphor-inventory-manager/associations.json#L94

Fan associations are implemented in phosphor-hwmon based on what we define in associations.json.

Latest patch is tested in Witherspoon.
Might be good to mention this was tested on Witherspoon in the commit msg. You could also add this link to the associations file. Up to you
Done
Need to handle null cases, similar to the existing sensor code.
Done
Yep, similar to what gunnar posted.  I see a < 0.0 check, which is not what I asked for.  This comment isn't done.
Done

We just leave it off if it is null? 
That is different than https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/e1bf8bb6a843a2a53d74d74f410b5fe053c2d222/redfish-core/lib/sensors.hpp#L934 but I think that is fine for this commit but can you put that in the commit msg and/or a comment in the code
Done

> but I think that is fine for this commit

I don't, and the more important thing is that this commit completely ignored the existing sensor code that handles this already.  This was discussed with DMTF on how to handle, and what's in the sensor subsystem is what they said.  I don't want to lose that, because we already lost it once in the other discussion for sensors.

Also, it's a trivial thing to add.  I'm not sure why it's that difficult to look at the old code.
I was not aware that these changes were made following a discussion. I simply followed the approach we typically use for other properties in bmcweb. I will make the necessary changes.
Done
Target, is different than SpeedRPM.  SpeedRPM is the current reading, Target is the target.  Surely this would've shown in your testing that SpeedRPM showed no noise when you ran your tests?

I see that the sensor’s code “Reading” is being set to the “Value” of the sensor.
I misunderstood the SpeedRPM, but I have now corrected the code.
This association doesn't exist anywhere that I see;  I don't understand how this code could've worked as written.

These associations are defined in associations.json file. 
https://github.com/openbmc/openbmc/blob/master/meta-ibm/recipes-phosphor/inventory/phosphor-inventory-manager/associations.json#L94

Why was this resolved?  One systems association does not mean it's correct.  Also, generally the association we've used is "all_sensors" so I'm a little surprised phosphor-inventory-manager accepted that.

Given that a fan very likely has multiple sensors of various classes, just looking for the first related sensor doesn't work.

There are other systems also have similar associations,
https://grok.openbmc.org/xref/openbmc/openbmc/meta-quanta/meta-gbs/recipes-phosphor/inventory/phosphor-inventory-manager/associations.json?r=b4ebad6c#286

There are other systems that have similar associations. 

https://grok.openbmc.org/xref/openbmc/openbmc/meta-quanta/meta-gbs/recipes-phosphor/inventory/phosphor-inventory-manager/associations.json?r=b4ebad6c#286

https://grok.openbmc.org/xref/openbmc/openbmc/meta-inspur/meta-fp5280g2/recipes-phosphor/inventory/phosphor-inventory-manager/associations.json?r=c0060a74#108

I will make changes to the code to filter the list of sensors that have 'fan_tach' in the path and pass it to addFanSensorsSpeedPercent. This approach aligns with what we've done in the sensor code. Please let me know if it is not necessary in this code if fans will have only sensors in 'fan_tach'.

https://grok.openbmc.org/xref/openbmc/bmcweb/redfish-core/lib/sensors.hpp?r=80f79a40#2581

> There are other systems also have similar associations,

Cool, that doesn't make them correct.


> I will make changes to the code to filter the list of sensors that have 'fan_tach' in the path and pass it to addFanSensorsSpeedPercent

and how will you determine the first fan tach from the second for dual rotor fans?  Or do you intend to not support dual rotor fans (in which case, the code needs to explicitly handle that case).

> This approach aligns with what we've done in the sensor code.

The sensor code relies on an all_sensors association, which I don't see that you've talked about changing, or even documenting the new association.


I have no idea why you linked the line of code that's creating the URI from the type....  Given that you don't have an odata.id for this property, it's unrelated.

> The sensor code relies on an all_sensors association, which I don't see that you've talked about changing, or even documenting the new association.

all_sensors is for the chassis to sensors. 
sensors is for a low level inventory item (like fan) to a sensor 
https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/717d273cf8bceac3868a278aeb34d19e8d74c1b3/architecture/sensor-architecture.md?plain=1#L66

> and how will you determine the first fan tach from the second for dual rotor fans? Or do you intend to not support dual rotor fans (in which case, the code needs to explicitly handle that case).

Do you need new associations here? 
For a single rotor, I could see where you only put it out if you have 1 assocation but for dual rotor, how do you know which is primary and which is secondary?

Do you need a primaryRPMsensor and secondaryRPMsenosr?
https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/blob/master/yaml/xyz/openbmc_project/Inventory/Item/Fan.interface.yaml#L4

> all_sensors is for the chassis to sensors.

We previously stated that we're not making association names specific to the type of hardware connected at the other end, so this would mean that "all_sensors" needs to be the same for fan -> Sensor and chassis -> Sensor, right?

"all_sensors" is going from chassis to sensor.
"sensors" is going from inventory item to sensor
https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/80f55a589d474e40cef0f9b6ee728098b8da159d/architecture/sensor-architecture.md?plain=1#L108

https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/80f55a589d474e40cef0f9b6ee728098b8da159d/architecture/sensor-architecture.md?plain=1#L66

This appears to go from the fan to the sensor so "sensors" is correct.

> "all_sensors" is going from chassis to sensor.

There might be chassis in the association name, but as code is currently written can go from any inventory item to a sensor.

https://github.com/openbmc/dbus-sensors/blob/16d6f17bec38b6c095dfb6bed224f17d941fb9b3/src/Utils.cpp#L584

If we want to change that, that's a very different commit.


> "sensors" is going from inventory item to sensor
> https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/80f55a589d474e40cef0f9b6ee728098b8da159d/architecture/sensor-architecture.md?plain=1#L108

That's nice, but the reality is that code doesn't follow the documentation, which is especially weird when the documentation was written AFTER the code.  If we want to fix that, that's a different discussion, but at this point in time, bmcweb uses all_sensors, and has for a LOOOOOOOONNG time.  Changing that will break anyone that's implemented a sensor downstream, which we can debate if we care about, but the fixes to upstream daemons need to come ahead of features that rely on those fixes.

> 
> https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/80f55a589d474e40cef0f9b6ee728098b8da159d/architecture/sensor-architecture.md?plain=1#L66
> 
> This appears to go from the fan to the sensor so "sensors" is correct.

Not in code it isn't.

Also, I know Gunnar can find this, but for documentation to anyone else that wants to help with this effort, this is where bmcweb currently maps inventory items to a sensor:

https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/8615915cc51a468c1c0b6eabb684616d0f2abe0f/redfish-core/lib/chassis.hpp#L480

A redfish "Chassis" can be of type Item.Board or Item.Chassis, so saying that the all_sensors->chassis association is only used for Item.Chassis isn't correct.

I'd also mention that the documentation pointed out earlier has an all_sensors association: https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/80f55a589d474e40cef0f9b6ee728098b8da159d/architecture/sensor-architecture.md?plain=1#L66

When this association was first made "chassis" was used in the redfish terms of "Contains things", not in the sense of "Is a piece of sheet metal that has stuff in it".  A fan functionally contains its sensors, so a fan sensor would be associated with the fan item.

The options I see are:
1. What this patchset proposes, use the associations inconsistently, with the only example being hardcoded examples in an IBM platform, and keep all_sensors in the sensor schema, while using sensors association in the ThermalSubsystem schema.
2. Change the existing all_sensors->chassis associations to use sensors, so we're consistent.  This breaks everyone that implemented a downstream sensor, which at this point we might not care about, but we should consider the implications on rebasing.
3. use the all_sensors association, make a minor change to one ibm platform to change a "sensor" association to "all_sensors" and be done with it.


FWIW, I think 3 is the easiest.  1 I'm not really interested in supporting.  We've been burned too many times using DBus inconsistently.  2 would be viable, but someone would have to put up the patches and do the work, and I don't think breaking everyone downstream is worthwhile for what amounts to a difference in naming.

This runs under the assumption that the sensors are in primary->secondary order.  Please don't make that assumption (as it's not true in a lot of cases).

Probably, especially given that a fan might have many sensors, only one of which is the primary tach, the associations need to be more specific.  Lets discuss in the PDI review adding those associations, rather than here.  Ideally the PDI discussion would've happened BEFORE this review was published, or before the associations were accepted into rainier, but oh well.
